Efficient  road  transport  services  are  needed  to  realize  the  full

connect  major  growth  centers,  supported  by  a  system  of  local 
roads;  (ii) developing  and  improving  urban  transport  and  rural 
roads;  (iii) promoting  road  safety;  (iv)  reducing  vehicle  emissions

and  efficiency  of  expressway  organizations;  and  (vi) promoting 
sustainable transport.  
 
The project is consistent with the PRC’s development priorities and 
ADB's country partnership strategy for the PRC (2008–2010), which 
seek  to  promote  inclusive  growth  and  environmentally  sustainable 
transport.  
 

The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  more  balanced  economic 
development in Heilongjiang province. The outcome will be a more 
resource-efficient,  safe,  and  environment-friendly  road  transport 
system in Heilongjiang province.

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
The  PRC  has  achieved  rapid  economic  growth;  gross  domestic  product  growth  has 
exceeded  9.0%  per  year  since  the  1980s.  Sustained  economic  growth  has  resulted  in  an 
unprecedented  expansion  of  traffic  between  and  within  provinces.  The  economy’s  changing 
structure  and  increasing  diversification  have  altered  the  pattern  of  transport  demand.  The 
movement of goods and passengers by road, which is more flexible and responsive to market 
needs than other modes of transport, is increasing rapidly.  
 
Propelling  the  country’s  robust  growth  and  rapid  poverty  reduction  were  massive 
3. 
investments in roads. As a result, by the end of 2006, a total of 3.457 million kilometers (km) of 
roads  were  opened  to  traffic;  100%  of  counties,  98.3%  of  townships,  and  86.4%  of 
administrative  villages  were  connected  by  roads.  At  the  end  of  the  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan,  the 
total length of expressways reached 45,300 km, class I highways 45,300 km, class II highways 
262,700  km,  class  III  highways  354,700  km,  class  IV  highways  1,574  million  km,  and 
unclassified roads 1,174 million km. The government’s policy for road subsector, as reflected in 
the Eleventh Five-Year Plan (2006–2010), calls for (i)  construction of 38,000 km of new roads 
to  bring  the  total  length  of  expressways  to  65,000 km;  (ii)   completion  of  the  35,000  km 
National Trunk  Highway  System;  and  (iii)  completion  of  the  7,918  km  network1 reflected  in  the 
Western Region Development Plan. 
 
Even  though  rural  roads  play  a  significant  role  in  poverty  reduction,  the  rural  road 
4. 
network, which accounts for 85% of the country’s total road network, is underdeveloped in both 
accessibility and technical standards. Thus, the 30 million rural poor face significant challenges 
in  relation  to  transport.  Many  live  in  isolated  villages,  thereby  restricting  their  access  to  basic 
goods and services. Most rural roads, especially in western PRC, are in poor condition due to 
limitations  in  design,  construction,  and  inadequate  maintenance;  and  damage  caused  by 
overloaded  vehicles.  The

class III highways  or  above.  Village  roads  are  even  worse,  with  only  2%  of  class  III  or  above. 
Only  20%  of  county  roads,  15%  of  township  roads,  and  9%  of  village  roads  are  paved.  About 
71%  of  rural  roads  are  dirt  roads  that  serve  many  townships  and  villages.  These  have  no 
drainage system, making them unsuitable for motorized traffic and impassable during the rainy 
season,  preventing  the  rural  poor  from  taking  advantage  of  jobs  created  by  economic  growth. 
The  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan  assigns  high  priority  to  rural  road  development  to  promote 
economic growth and reduce poverty in rural areas. At the beginning of 2005, the government 
launched  a  Rural  Road  Construction  Program  aiming  that  by  2010  paved  roads  will  link  all 
eastern  villages,  80%  of  the  central  villages,  and  90%  of  western  villages.  The  government 
plans to complete 1.2 million km of rural roads under the Eleventh Five-Year Plan.

construction  of  national  and  provincial  trunk  highway  networks.  Substantial  funds  have  been 
used for rural road development. However, funding for road maintenance has been inadequate.

In  recent  years,  road  development  has  been  funded  mainly  by  domestic  banks,  local 
governments and Ministry of Transport grants. Expressways and class I highways are expected 
to  cover  their  operating  and  maintenance  costs  and  debt  service  charges  from  toll  revenues. 
Domestic  debt  has  been  increasingly  used  to  finance  expressways  and  other  road  projects, 
repaid  from  toll  revenues.  On  1  January  2009,  the  State  Council  introduced  a  new  policy  to 
implement collection of a fuel tax and abolish the collection of road maintenance fees and five 
other  transportation  fees.  The  consumption  tax  levied  as  part  of  the  fuel  price  was  increased 
from CNY0.2 to CNY1.0 per liter for gasoline, and from CNY0.1 to CNY0.8 per liter for diesel. 
Revenues from the fuel tax are expected to be allocated initially to each province in proportion to 
their 2007 vehicle maintenance fee revenues.  
 
6. 
In addition to the construction and maintenance of road infrastructure, the improvement 
of transport services for passengers and goods is an important part of improving rural transport. 
In 2008, the number of passengers traveling by roads reached 1,247.6 billion passenger-km, an 
increase  of  54.0%  of  total  transport  by  all  modes,  while  the  volume  of  goods  transported 
reached 3,286.8 billion ton-km, an increase of 12.3%. The government has been giving priority 
to  improving  rural  passenger  transport.  By  the  end  of  2008,  about  99.2%  of  townships  and 
92.8% of administrative villages had regular bus services. The services are mainly provided by 
private  transport  companies  and  based  on  market  needs.  However,  villages  with  fewer 
passengers  often  lack  adequate  bus  services.  Appropriate  government  policies  are  needed  to 
regulate rural village bus services and improve bus service quality. 
 
7. 
The  government  recognizes  the  importance  of  road  safety  and  has  been  implementing 
various initiatives and programs including the National Road Safety Law, approved in 2004. This

2007. 2 However,  this  rate  is  still  relatively  high  when  compared  with  developed  countries. 3

Heilongjiang, a landlocked province in the extreme northeast of the PRC, is bordered by 
the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region (Inner Mongolia) in the west, the Russian Federation in 
the north and east, and Jilin province in the south. With an area of 454,000 square kilometers

its products has consistently risen. However, since the 1980s Heilongjiang has fallen behind the 
coastal provinces. In 1982, its per capita gross domestic product was about the same as that of 
the coastal provinces (Jiangsu, Shanghai, and Zhejiang); by 2008, it had dropped to 50%.

Problems and Constraints 

 
10. 
Despite huge investment, the PRC road network still does not provide all-weather access 
to large parts of the country, particularly the poorer inland regions, and is not sufficient to sustain 
economic  growth.  Expanding  demand  for  road  transport  has  strained  road  infrastructure,  as 
manifested  by  missing  links  and  bottlenecks  in  the  network.  The  resulting  high  cost  of 
transporting goods between inland provinces and ports has been a serious constraint for inland 
provinces,  including  Heilongjiang.  In  Heilongjiang,  the  road  network  is  concentrated  around 
Harbin, and the roads serving the far north, east, and west still need to be improved. Due to lack 
of  road  network  connectivity  and  the  low  technical  standard  of  the  roads,  the  transport  cost  is 
high and the access to the remote rural hinterland is one of the main constraints for rural poverty 
reduction. 
 
11. 
Natural resources and industrial production in the province are geographically dispersed. 
Xiaoxinganling  mountain  provides  a  barrier  to  developing  an  adequate  transport  corridor 
between  the  northeast  and  northwest  part  of  the  province.  Sanjiang  Plain,  a  major  agricultural 
and  coal  mining  area,  is  located  in  the  northeast,  while  Harbin–Daqing–Qiqihar,  a  center  for 
heavy  industries  and  the  Songnen  Plain  farming  area  are  located  in  the  west  and  northwest. 
Two  prominent  tourism  destinations,  Wudalianchi  and  Yichun,  are  located  in  the  northwest. 
Currently,  travelers  have  to  take  a  long  detour  via  Harbin  to  reach  Wudalianchi  and  Yichun. 
Road  transport  between  the  east  and  west  is  therefore  costly,  inefficient  in  use  of  natural 
resources, and involves high consumption of fuel, greenhouse gas emissions, and a high road 
traffic  accident  toll.  This  is  a  constraint  for  socioeconomic  development  and  for  reducing 
development disparities in the province.

and (iv) strengthening measures to enforce road safety law and regulations. In 2007, it issued 
the Heilongjiang Road Traffic Safety Regulations4 and established new requirements for drivers, 
vehicles,  roads,  pedestrians,  accident  treatment,  and  monitoring  of  legal  responsibilities. 
However, issues such as traffic regulation enforcement, overloaded vehicles, restriction of use 
of  unregistered  and  unsafe  vehicles,  improvement  of  road  user  behavior,  and  provision  of 
effective  emergency  response  measures  still  must  be  addressed.  Advanced  technologies  and 
methods used in developed countries could be introduced to improve road safety.

Economic Analysis 

62. 
The  project  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  was  estimated  by  comparing  the 
without-project  and  with-project  scenarios  for  four  road  sections:  Yichun–Bei’an,  Bei’an–
Wudalianchi,  Longzhen–Nenjiang,  and  Nenjiang–Inner  Mongolia  border  (Appendix  12).  The 
economic costs include (i) the capital cost for construction including physical contingencies, and 
land  acquisition  and  resettlement;  (ii) costs  for  environmental  management  and  monitoring, 
detailed engineering design, and construction supervision; and (iii) annualized recurring costs for 
road maintenance, environmental monitoring, and opportunity cost of land. The economic benefits 
are  (i)  savings  in  travel  time,  vehicle  operating  costs,  and  traffic  accidents  costs;  and 
(ii) generated traffic. The project is economically viable. The economic internal rate of return for 
the whole project is 17.79%; the rates for the four road sections range from 14.04% to 19.36%. 
Sensitivity tests confirm the robustness of the project’s economic viability.

economic  development,  especially  for  the  transportation  of  energy,  minerals,  materials,  and 
other bulk cargo.  
 
By  the  end  of  2007,  Heilongjiang  had  a  road  network  of  140,909  km, with  a  density  of 
3. 
31 km  per  hundred  square  km,  lower  than  the  country’s  average  density.  By  technical 
classification,  the  road  network  comprises  1,044  km  of  expressways,  1,435  km  of  class  I 
highways, 7,443 km of class II highways, 33,207 km of class III roads, and 50,883 km of class 
IV roads. 
 
4. 
Inland  waterway  transport  in  Heilongjiang  province  is  mainly  along  the  Heilongjiang 
River,  Wusuli  River,  Songhua  River  and  Nen  River;  comprising  5,528  km  of  navigable 
waterways.  Water  ports  are  mainly  located  along  Songhua  River  and  Heilongjiang  River, 
including  the  main  ports  of  Fuyuan,  Harbin,  Heihe,  Jiamusi,  and  Tongjiang.  The  system  has 
172 passenger and freight berths, with annual freight capacity of 15 million tons, and capacity 
for 1.8 million passengers. 
 
5. 
Currently, Heilongjiang province has five civil airports, located at Harbin, Heihe, Jiamusi, 
Mudanjiang,  and  Qiqihar.  Harbin  Taiping  Airport  is  an  international  airport  and  the  second 
largest airport in the northeast of the PRC. More than 60 air routes form an aviation network to 
all provinces of the country, and Japan, the Republic of Korea, and the Russian Federation. 
 
6. 
Alongside robust socioeconomic development and transport infrastructure improvement, 
passenger  and  freight  traffic  in  Heilongjiang  province  have  grown  rapidly.  During  2000–2007, 
total  passenger  traffic  increased  by  30%;  and  total  freight  traffic  increased  by  28%.  Despite 
competition  among  transport  modes  in  recent  years,  railway  transportation  is  still  dominant  in 
freight  transportation  due  to  its  low  price  and  high  reliability.  However,  a  significant  amount  of 
medium  and  short-distance  passenger  traffic  has  diverted  from  railway  to  road.  During  2000–
2007,  passenger  road  traffic  increased  by  an  annual  average  of  4.72%  and  freight  traffic  by 
4.03% per annum.

planning, development, maintenance, and administration of the road and waterway subsectors 
on behalf of the provincial government. HPTD is mainly responsible for national and provincial 
highways,  including  planning,  financing,  construction,  operation,  and  maintenance.  Prefecture 
and county communications bureaus are responsible for construction and maintenance of local 
roads.  HPTD  also  regulates  the  road  transport  industry  by  licensing  drivers,  vehicles,  and

policy to abolish the collection of road maintenance fees and five other types of transportation 
fees, and to start collection of fuel tax.

Heilongjiang Road Sector Development Plan 

9. 
To  stimulate  and  maintain  high  socioeconomic  development,  in  June  2008  the 
Heilongjiang  government  approved  a  3-year  plan  for  speeding  up  road  development.  It  will

CNY90 billion  to  develop  2,207  km  of  expressways,  731 km  of  class  I  highways,  3,252  km  of 
class II highways, and 60,799 km of rural roads.

to unskilled labor, but not on the wages paid to skilled labor, because no skilled worker surplus 
exists.  A  shadow  wage  rate  factor  of  0.67  was  used  to  convert  the  financial  wage  rate  to  an

physical  contingencies,  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  and  environmental  mitigation  costs; 
and  (ii)  the  costs  of  operating  and  maintaining  the  roads,  including  the  costs  of  replacing 
depreciated  equipment.  The  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  costs  are  based  on  their 
opportunity  costs  calculated  by  the  National  Development  Reform  Commission's  methodology

Economic Benefits 

C. 
 
6. 
Vehicle  operating  cost  savings.  Vehicle  operating  cost  savings  are  the  differences 
between  with-  and  without-project  cases.  The  PPK  model2  was  utilized  to  estimate  vehicle 
operating costs in both cases. Data for the PPK model were collected from pertinent sources in 
the province. In this respect, the following data were acquired: prices of vehicles, tires, fuel and 
lubricants; maintenance labor cost, crew wages, and annual overhead cost; annual interest rate; 
and  time  value  of  passengers  and  freight.  For  each  vehicle  type,  the  model  assumes  specific 
parameter  values  describing  the  vehicle’s  configuration,  engineering  characteristics,  operation, 
and cost. For estimation of the vehicle operating cost (VOC) savings, the international roughness 
index is assumed to be 6 using without-project conditions and 2 using with-project conditions. 
 
Time  savings  benefits.  Using  the  vehicle  operating  speeds  of  the  traffic  assignment 
7. 
model, the total passenger-hours and freight ton-hours are estimated for with- and without-project 
assumptions.  In  estimating  the  time  value  for  passengers,  the  following  parameters  are  used: 
(i) the  gross  domestic  product  per  capita  of  CNY21,727  in  2008,  (ii)  total  working  hours  for 
passengers is 2,000,3 and (iii) hourly rates of CNY10.86. 
 
8. 
Generated  traffic  benefits.  The  new  roads  will  generate  new  traffic.  The  benefits  of 
generated traffic are estimated on the basis of cost savings to generated traffic. The generated 
traffic benefits are valued at 50% of the VOC savings used for normal and diverted traffic.  
 
9. 
Accident savings. Road traffic accidents resulted in costs of CNY150, 000 for fatalities, 
CNY 100,000 for injuries, and CNY30,000 for property damage. In 2008, the total number of road 
accidents  in  Heilongjiang  Province  was  4,538  with  1,703  fatalities  and  4,905  injuries,  this 
represents a decrease from 2007 of 32.57% for total number of accidents, 10.65% for fatalities, 
and  34.36%  for  injuries  from  2007.  Property  damages  were  estimated  at  CNY20.06  million,  a 
decrease  of  23.4%.  In  estimating  benefits  to  accident  reduction,  cost  per  km  was  estimated  at 
CNY0.04187  per  vehicle-km.  In  the  case  of  normal  and  generated  traffic,  5%  of  the  estimated 
accident  cost  was  attributed,  which  was  then  multiplied  by  the  annual  average  daily  traffic  and 
road length to estimate the total accident benefits. In the case of diverted traffic, the full accident 
cost  per  vehicle-km  was  considered  and  then multiplied  by  the  annual  average  daily  traffic  and 
reduced road length.

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The  PRC  has  made  good  progress  in  poverty  reduction  over  the  last  25  years,  but  it  is  still  facing  a  big  challenge  in 
addressing poverty. Poor accessibility or isolation can inhibit economic and social development. The road subsector is 
one  of  the  most  important  areas  for  poverty  reduction.  Roads  provide  (i)  improved  access  for  the  poor  to  external 
markets, employment opportunities, and social services; (ii) lower transport costs of agricultural inputs and produce; and 
(iii)  improved  interaction  with  other  regions,  thus  providing  opportunities  to  develop  and  exploit  comparative  and 
competitive advantages. Increased economic activities and urbanization of the project area can lead to increasing local 
employment opportunities (e.g., commercial agriculture, eco-forestry, and other tourism).  
 
The  project  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  PRC  country  strategy  and  program,a  especially  pillar  I  of  Inclusive  Growth  and 
Balanced  Development.  Under  this  pillar  I,  ADB  will  help  the  PRC  build  a  harmonious  society  and  boost  rural 
development in areas where growth and development are lagging. The central government has a program to revitalize 
the  northeast  region  as  an  industrial  hub,  and  the  regional  transport  network  development  plan  is  an  important 
component of this program. Also, the Heilongjiang Poverty Reduction Development Regulation prioritizes transport. 
 
The project will continue ADB's engagement with the Heilongjiang provincial government in the transport sector. It will 
provide  more  reliable  and  safe  transport  services  to  local  people,  which  will  contribute  to  economic  development, 
livelihood improvement, and indirect poverty reduction. The highway will establish a direct connection between Yichun 
and Bei’an, and improve transport between Wudalianchi and Nenjiang. Integrated with improving the local road network, 
the highway will improve transport between the forestry area in east and agricultural area in west, promote trade of the 
two  areas,  and  add  economic  value  to  their  production  of  grains,  nontimber  forest  products,  and  livestock,  as  well  as 
facilitate 
infrastructure  services  (e.g.,  health,  education,  water,  and 
telecommunications) to be upgraded by local government.

1.  Key Issues  

The  poverty  analysis  is  based  on  published  statistical  data,  socioeconomic  questionnaire  survey  of  513  households, 
focus  group  discussions,  and  key  informant  interviews  in  the  project  area.  Heilongjiang  is  an  agricultural  and  forestry

48 townships and towns along the proposed highway corridor are categorized as poverty population. Most of the rural 
poor are living in 50 poverty villages, while the rest are scattered in nonpoverty villages. Poverty is also present on the 
state forest farms. The causes of poverty in the project area include poor quality farmland in mountainous areas, poor 
irrigation systems, poor transportation conditions, and natural disasters. In state forest farms, the main causes of poverty

The  improved  access  afforded  by  the  proposed  highway  and  bus  services  will  remove  transport  constraints  and

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

Stakeholder analysis was conducted as part of the poverty and social assessment for this project. The key stakeholders 
include  town  and  township  residents,  state  farm  workers,  state  forest  workers,  small  businesses,  adversely  affected 
people,  HPTD,  and  the  implementing  agencies.  Other  government  stakeholders  include  Civil  Affairs  Bureau,  Labor, 
Forestry,  Poverty  Reduction  Office,  Health  Bureau,  women’s  federation,  and  Religious  and  Minority  Affairs  Bureau. 
During  project  preparation,  a  socioeconomic  survey  of  513  households,  stakeholder  consultation  workshops,  focus 
group discussions, and key informant interviews were conducted to gain a better understanding of the demands, needs, 
and interests of the stakeholders.  
 
The project roads will benefit 512,000 people in 48 townships, towns, state farms, and state forest farms; the improved 
rural  transport  services  will  benefit  431,500  people  in  12  townships,  towns,  state  farms,  and  state  forest  farms.  The 
western section of the project area is mainly a farming region,  where agricultural production and profitability has been 
good the past decade. The eastern section of the project area is mountainous and mainly forested; however, the state 
forest farms are not profitable due to the ban on logging old forests. The proposed highway will link these two areas and 
enable the local economies to become more diversified and integrated. Also, the highway will encourage more tourism 
businesses by linking the forest-based tourism in Yichun with tourism based on the old volcanic formation and springs in 
Wudalianchi.  
 
The  potential  adverse  social  impacts  from  the  project  include  (i)  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  (ii)  increased 
accidents due to higher speeds and mixed traffic, (iii) transmissible diseases spread by the large construction workforce, 
and (iv) disruption to local communities during construction. Mitigations measures to address these issues are included 
in the resettlement plans  and the social development  action plan (SDAP). A few ethnic minority villages in the  project 
area can benefit from the project; they will not be adversely impacted. HPTD and the local government have agreed to 
take following actions to enhance project benefits for five ethnic minority villages: (i) integrated poverty reduction, road 
improvement and tourism development programs, and (ii) cultural protection and development.
